title: Understanding Gibbs Free Energy
text:
To determine which allotrope is more stable, we need to calculate the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) for each. The formula for Gibbs free energy is:

ΔG $$=$$ ΔH - TΔS.

Use this formula to calculate ΔG for both yellow and monoclinic sulfur at $$298$$ K.

title: Calculating Gibbs Free Energy for Yellow Sulfur
text:
For yellow sulfur:

ΔH°_f $$=$$ $$0$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$
S° $$=$$ $$31.88$$ $$ rac{J}{mol·K}$$ $$=$$ $$0.03188$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol·K}$$

Substituting these values into the Gibbs free energy equation:
ΔG $$=$$ $$0$$ - $$298$$ × $$0.03188$$

title: Calculating ΔG for Yellow Sulfur
text: Calculate ΔG for yellow sulfur using:\nΔG $$=$$ $$0$$ - $$298$$ × $$0.03188$$

title: Calculating Gibbs Free Energy for Monoclinic Sulfur
text:
For monoclinic sulfur:

ΔH°_f $$=$$ $$0.30$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$
S° $$=$$ $$32.60$$ $$ rac{J}{mol·K}$$ $$=$$ $$0.03260$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol·K}$$

Substituting these values into the Gibbs free energy equation:
ΔG $$=$$ $$0.30$$ - $$298$$ × $$0.03260$$

title: Calculating ΔG for Monoclinic Sulfur
text: Calculate ΔG for monoclinic sulfur using:\nΔG $$=$$ $$0.30$$ - $$298$$ × $$0.03260$$

title: Comparing the Gibbs Free Energy Values
text:
Now that we've calculated the Gibbs free energy for both forms, compare the two values:
- ΔG for yellow sulfur
- ΔG for monoclinic sulfur

The form with the lower Gibbs free energy is more thermodynamically stable.

title: Final Decision on Stability
text:
Based on the calculated ΔG values:
- ΔG for yellow sulfur $$=$$ $$-9.5$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$
- ΔG for monoclinic sulfur $$=$$ $$-9.398$$ $$ rac{kJ}{mol}$$

Which allotrope is more stable at $$298$$ K?
choices: Temperature plays no role in the stability of these allotropes.
